display_asset.caption: Tammy Duckworth, Democrat of Illinois, lost both of her legs when her helicopter was hit by a rocket-propelled grenade in 2004.

summaries.body: A Republican committee deleted its Twitter post that said Tammy Duckworth, an Iraq veteran and double amputee, has a “sad record of not standing up for our veterans.”
Women who make the first move in online dating​ are rewarded with more desirable men, according to an OkCupid study of 70,000 users.

display_asset.caption: Firefighters at the scene of a building explosion in Seattle early Wednesday.

summaries.body: An overnight explosion in Seattle leveled two buildings and injured at least nine firefighters. A natural gas leak was confirmed as the cause.

display_asset.caption: Coverage of the Go master Lee Se-dol’s loss to Google DeepMind’s AlphaGo in the first match of the best-of-five series in Seoul, South Korea, on Wednesday.
display_asset.credit: Yonhap News Agency, via European Pressphoto Agency

summaries.body: A Google computer trounced one of the world’s top players in a round of Go, which is believed to be the most complex board game ever created.

display_asset.caption: Shruthi Aramandla, 24, a native of India who received a master’s degree in engineering from New York University in May, said she would be able to stay longer in the United States under the new rule.

summaries.body: International students earning degrees in science and technology fields in the United States will now be eligible to stay for three years of on-the-job training.

display_asset.caption: A crowd gathered in Jakarta, Indonesia’s capital, on Wednesday to observe the total solar eclipse, which was visible in nearly half of the country’s 34 provinces.

summaries.body: Millions of Indonesians witnessed a total solar eclipse early on Wednesday, the first since March 20 of last year.
For all the urgent issues President Obama is facing, his health doesn't appear to be one of them. Tests showed a lower weight and an improved heart rate compared with 2014.
“Hostel-like” hotels may be part of Hilton’s strategy as the company tries to attract young travelers seeking cheaper rooms.

display_asset.caption: Cyrena Lee, in front of the Whole Foods Market in Gowanus, Brooklyn. Solar energy is in keeping with the company’s image, but it will also save the company money.
display_asset.credit: Dolly Faibyshev for The New York Times

summaries.body: Whole Foods is planning to install about 100 rooftop solar power systems to reduce costs as it faces increasing competition from other stores selling organic goods.

display_asset.caption: Times Square is a top attraction for tourists in New York City, but officials hope to lure visitors to explore the city’s other boroughs.

summaries.body: New York City’s tourism agency is forecasting a record 59.7 million visitors in 2016. Last year, England, Canada and Brazil sent the most foreign visitors.

display_asset.caption: Shaun Cunningham saved his son Landon from a flying bat during a spring training game in Florida on Saturday.

summaries.body: A flying baseball bat, a dad’s instinct and a photograph. In a split second, a risky moment became a picture that has dazzled the Internet.
John Oliver sold out of “Make Donald Drumpf Again" caps after the presidential candidate became the focus of his show, "Last Week Tonight."

display_asset.caption: Calvin Johnson ends with 731 career receptions for 11,619 yards and 83 touchdowns.

summaries.body: Calvin Johnson, one of the best receivers in football, said he was retiring from the Detroit Lions after just nine seasons.

display_asset.caption: Nine people were injured near Sunol, Calif., when an Altamont Corridor Express train derailed on Monday.
display_asset.credit: Alameda County Fire Department, via European Pressphoto Agency

summaries.body: A commuter train derailed and plunged into a creek in Northern California late Monday, injuring nine passengers. The overnight rescue operation was well documented on social media.

display_asset.caption: A market in the mixed Jewish and Arab city of Lod in central Israel. A Pew study found that only 1 percent of Israel’s Muslim, Christian and Druze minorities said they had a spouse of a different religion.
display_asset.credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times

summaries.body: In its first in-depth study of religion in Israel, the Pew Research Center found deep rifts among Israeli Jews on issues like Israeli settlements in the West Bank.

display_asset.caption: Matthew Healy of the 1975 performing in London on Saturday.

summaries.body: The 1975, a young British pop-rock band, opened at No. 1 on the Billboard chart with its new album, which the group withheld from Spotify for its first two weeks.

display_asset.caption: A total solar eclipse showing the sun’s corona as seen from Australia on Nov. 13 2012.

summaries.body: A total solar eclipse will begin on Wednesday and end the previous day on the other side of the international date line.
New research suggests that taking pictures of food before eating it can actually make the food taste better.
A woman in China was trapped and forgotten in a broken elevator of her apartment building for more than a month before her body was discovered last week.
A suspect in a van painted to look like the Mystery Machine from “Scooby Doo” led the police in California on a high-speed chase.
Hulk Hogan testified in his sex-tape lawsuit against Gawker, a battle highlighting the somewhat murky line between the right to privacy and the right to free speech.

display_asset.caption: Kim Ryen-hi, recalling her family in the North, wept in the dorm room where she lives in Yeongcheon, South Korea.
display_asset.credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times

summaries.body: The only North Korean defector who has publicly said she wants to leave South Korea has asked Vietnam to help her return to her home in the North.

display_asset.caption: An Apple Store in New York. Mac users are facing new security threats to their operating systems.

summaries.body: A software attack that forces users to pay for access to their own files successfully targeted a Mac operating system, piercing an image of safety long associated with Apple.

display_asset.caption: Emadeldin Elsayed, an Egyptian aviation student living in Los Angeles. This undated photo was provided by his brother Ohoud Ali Mohamed Nasr El Sayed.

summaries.body: An Egyptian student agreed to leave the U.S. after the Secret Service found his Facebook post saying he wouldn't mind "taking a lifetime sentence in jail for killing" Donald J. Trump.

display_asset.caption: Oberlin College’s board of trustees told the institution to consider action against Joy Karega, whose Facebook posts promoted Israel-United States conspiracy theories.
display_asset.credit: Dustin Franz for The New York Times

summaries.body: Oberlin's board of trustees told the college to consider action against a professor after it denounced Facebook comments she posted as "anti-Semitic and abhorrent."

display_asset.caption: A stenciled image attributed to Banksy depicting a poor child making Union flags on a sewing machine and is located on the wall of a Poundland discount shop in London.

summaries.body: Researchers using geographic profiling, used to track criminals, think they may have identified Banksy. The graffiti artist declined comment through a representative.

display_asset.caption: The front and back of a rare Ty Cobb baseball card, one of seven recently discovered cards.

summaries.body: A handful of century-old baseball cards featuring Ty Cobb may net $1 million for their owner after they were found while cleaning out a great-grandparent’s home.

display_asset.caption: The Oconee Nuclear Station in Seneca, S.C., in 2005.

summaries.body: A fire at the Oconee nuclear power plant in South Carolina partly shut down the facility on Sunday, but caused no threat to the public, the company said.

display_asset.caption: Tom Knight in 1982 at the grave site of Charles Ebbets, former owner of the Brooklyn Dodgers.

summaries.body: Tom Knight, the first and only official baseball historian of Brooklyn, has died at 89. He knew everything about the Dodgers.
The author of a new book about the rising power of unmarried women talks about what marriage has represented for women historically, and how it has changed.
